title: HUBweek starts Saturday. Here are 16 (free!) events to check out - Events
text:
You’ve probably heard about HUBweek but still don’t really understand what it is. It’s the first year for this week-long event so how do we know what to expect? HUBweek describes itself as a place where “art, science, and technology collide” and as an atmosphere where you can “ask why and why not.”
Basically, this is Boston’s answer to South By Southwest, but without the music— Boston Calling’s got that covered.
HUBweek is spread out over seven days and more than 10 areas within the city, from Kendall Square to the Seaport. Each of its more than 100 events falls into one of five featured topic categories: climate change and sustainability; future of learning and work; wellness and healthcare delivery; art and entertainment; and civic and social innovation.
Overwhelmed by all the action? Let us suggest some fun and free things to watch out for.
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 3
Let’s Talk About Food: 11:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Copley Square
This is actually the fourth annual Let’s Talk About Food Festival, a deep dive into the food we eat, with celebrity chefs, farmers, fishermen, nutritionists, and more. WBUR’s Bob Oakes will lead a discussion about the state of New England fisheries and the option of sea vegetables from Maine as a new sustainable main ingredient.
Kate Goble served up taco's at a previous Lets Talk About Food Festival. Jonathan Wiggs / The Boston Globe SUNDAY, OCTOBER 4
De-Stress Boston: 11:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m., Massachusetts General Hospital
Boston is a fast-paced city so we’ve all certainly dealt with stress. (We probably have the T to thank for some of that.) Relax with this guide to tension-busting techniques. Dr. Herbert Benson, a cardiologist and founder of the Mind Body Medical Institute at Mass General, and other experts will lead all-level yoga and tai chi classes to help even the most-tense but least-flexible unwind.
MONDAY, OCTOBER 5
Pilates in the Park: 6:00 to 8:00 p.m., New Balance Experience Store
If running isn’t your thing, New Balance still has you covered. Start HUBweek with the famed Pilates instructor Hanneke Antonelli. After meeting up at the NB Store, you’ll travel over to Copley Square Park to re-energize yourself in the heart of the city.
Celebrate Boston Party: 6:00 to 9:00 p.m., WeWork South Station
If you’re into the startup scene, that requires networking. Here’s a chance to meet techies, bloggers, culinary masters, and more in a party at WeWork South Station. WeWork is an office space where startups can buy or rent a spot. Now they’re hosting what is sure to be an epic 21+ party—more than 800 guests are expected to attend.
TUESDAY, OCTOBER 6
Driving Ourselves Happy: 6:00 to 7:00 p.m., Massachusetts General Hospital
There’s science behind the feeling of happiness, and evolutionary psychologist Dr. Nancy Etcoff will address why and how we strive for it. Join this discussion about the human pursuit for happiness and beauty, and hear Etcoff’s expertise on how you can change your life.
WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 7
Harvard Innovation Lab Startup Showcase and Celebration: 5:00 to 7:00 p.m., Harvard Innovation Lab
HUBweek is all about innovation, but this event takes that idea to another level: It lets you see, hear, taste, and touch things like insect snacks and working-robot hands. There’ll be product demonstrations left and right, but this event is standing room only, so get in while you can.
THURSDAY, OCTOBER 8
Converse Rubber Tracks Sample Creation Days: 10:00 a.m. to Friday, October 9 at 6:00 p.m., Converse World Headquarters
Don’t have enough money to book studio time and record that demo you’ve been singing in your shower? No worries, Converse is opening their Rubber Tracks Studio twice during HUBweek. You can play around with and even add your own sound to the Rubber Tracks Sample Library—a royalty-free online library of over 20,000 loops and sounds recorded in the studio.
Inside Kendall Square: 12:00 to 9:00 p.m., Kendall Square
This event offers a look into the magic of Kendall Square, an area filled with students, scientists, and entrepreneurs., Kendall Square is its own hub, buzzing with innovation, and even real bees—like at the What’s the Buzz on Urban Bees? event from 3:00 to 7:00 p.m. For food and fun, head to Patio Reggae Jam: Eat, Listen, Dance, 4:00 to 9:00 p.m. And to really dive into the benefits of local food, check out The Farmer’s Market @Kendall Square from 12:00 to 2:00 p.m.
FRIDAY, OCTOBER 9
New Balance Runs Boston: 12:15 to 1:15 p.m., New Balance Experience Store
Boston actually runs on New Balance—the sneaker company just completed its 250,000-square-foot World Headquarters in Allston-Brighton, and even made a limited edition shoe to help Bostonians run “ fastah .” At this event, Team New Balance Coach and Olympic Marathoner Mark Coogan will host a scenic 3.5- mile run through the city and along the Esplanade.
WorkBeat: Find Your Rhythm: 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Atlantic Wharf
WorkBeat is its own “pop-up community,” with all different events so you can work and play. From Lego building to yoga classes, Boloco burritos and a Boston by Foot tour of Fort Point Channel, there’s something for everyone here.
What Works: Closing the Gender Wage Gap in the City of Boston: 3:00 to 4:30 p.m., Harvard Kennedy School
Mayor Marty Walsh and the Boston Women’s Workforce Council have been working together to close the notorious gender wage gap, and now you can learn about how they plan to do so. This is a panel discussion with fierce female leaders, such as Iris Bohnet, director of the Women and Public Policy Program at Harvard Kennedy School, and Megan Costello, executive director of the Office of Women’s Advancement.
HUB Slam: A Live Storytelling Competition: 4:00 to 6:00 p.m., C Space
Love The Moth podcast but want a more Boston feel to your story slams? At this event, you can share tales of getting your Boston startup off the ground, the moment a brilliant idea was born in some beautiful Boston location, or a wild event that occurred in the wake of a Boston sports win. All speakers with a five-minute story are welcome.
The new Greenway mural, designed by MIT-sponsored artist Lawrence Weiner, will be on display in Dewey Square during the Block Party. David L Ryan / The Boston Globe HUBweek Block Party: 5:00 to 8:00 p.m., Dewey Square
The Greenway Conservancy, HUBweek, and IdeaPaint are celebrating public art on The Greenway with a free block party. There’ll be music, lawn games, $4 beer/wine, and a look at The Greenway’s latest mural by Lawrence Weiner.
“Redactions” at Boston City Hall: 7:00 to 9:00 p.m., Boston City Hall
It’s about time someone took advantage of the acoustics inside the enormous concrete mezzanine of Boston City Hall. Electronic musician and composer Keith Fullerton Whitman will perform a new piece on a modular synthesizer that will bounce off the Brutalist walls of the building.
SATURDAY, OCTOBER 10
Engineering + Entrepreneurship: Making Robotics Fly: 12:00 to 2:00 p.m., Harvard Stadium
Robots are probably going to take over the world one day so we better start learning as much as we can about them now. Plus, who hasn’t wanted to fly a drone? This event aims to “entertain, educate, and demystify” by showcasing a range of robotics, especially those “unmanned aerial vehicles” that are flying all around us.
Illuminus: 6:30 to 11:30 p.m., Lansdowne Street
This contemporary art festival will let you see the city like you’ve never seen it before. Fenway’s “Green Monster” will turn into a three-story percussion instrument. The floor will turn into a “Healing Pool,” where glowing and interacting patterns will react directly to your touch. Giant, animatronic white rhinoceroses will float above you. Basically: Boston will never look boring to you again.
